title: Disputes , chimneys and flags - the Birmingham stories that grabbed attention in 2025
body_text:
Disputes, chimneys and flags - the Birmingham stories that grabbed attention in 2025
In part two of my lookback at the biggest stories I covered in 2025, we take you from July to December
The first half of 2026 will be dominated by two major political issues in Birmingham - the ongoing bin strike, and the local elections that will give residents their say over the city's future.
But before we turn to what's ahead, I've been looking back at the main stories that exercised my time and dominated the headlines in the second half of 2025.
There's only one place to begin - and it's rubbish.
JULY
In an exclusive conversation with Unite's General Secretary Sharon Graham, a series of revelations emerged about private negotiations that had taken place aimed at getting a 'compensation' deal agreed for affected bin workers that did not also jeopardise the council's equal pay liabilities.
We learned that bin workers had allegedly been offered £10,000 compensation to 'go quietly' and end the strike.
Graham also produced private WhatsApp messages between her and council chief executive Joanne Roney which she claimed proved that commissioners had interfered to thwart the planned deal. Soon after all negotiations between the two parties were ended. They have not resumed in the six months since.
READ THE STORIES HERE
Revealed - Birmingham bin drivers offered £10,000 'compensation' to go quietly and end strike
WhatsApp messages between council chief and Unite boss 'prove commissioners running strike deal’
The bin strike has had huge ramifications inside the city council, with fingers pointed at the Labour leadership for their failure to end the dispute.
There were more barbs for the current leaders when a list of their selected candidates was revealed to stand in the 2026 election for Labour. Several veteran councillors were axed in a cull, triggering defections and fury. Questions were also asked about the credibility of some of those who had been chosen to stay and fight for Labour.
Sitting MPs were accused of influencing the choices unfairly - with Erdington MP Paulette Hamilton among those later accused of exercising nepotism to get relatives and allies chosen for seats deemed 'safe' for Labour.
READ MORE: Massive Labour shocks at Birmingham City Council as veteran councillors axed by party
READ MORE: Anger as Birmingham Labour MP faces nepotism claim over choice of council candidates
This was also the month when alternatives to the mainstream parties in Birmingham began to plot and prepare for the 2026 local election battles.
Birmingham MP Ayoub Khan was at the centre of the launch of new left wing party Your Party with Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana. It was to later run into turmoil but Khan remains keen for the project to prosper into 2026.
Meanwhile, pro-Palestine independents across the city were coalescing around Akhmed Yakoob and Shakeel Afsar, two prominent figures in Birmingham politics.
Labour defectors were checking out both options - where many of them end up will become clear early in the new year.
Nigel Farage's Reform UK also set out its stall. The party held its conference in the city and its regional director revealed a plan to stand a Reform candidate in every council seat in the region, including all 101 seats in Birmingham.
Reform to stand in every council seat in Birmingham and Black Country in massive push for power
In a sudden, unexpected move, the lead commissioner who had been sent in to oversee troubled Birmingham City Council, Max Caller, announced his retirement. He had been a controversial presence in the city, as was clear from the reaction to his departure.
The month ended on a low note, when much loved Moseley campaigner and city councillor Kerry Jenkins died after a short but devastating illness.
AUGUST
Away from the Birmingham political bubble, I received a tip-off about a children's home in the area that was badly letting down young people left in its care, at considerable public expense. What was then uncovered was a catalogue of misery, with children going missing and unsafe from properties which were utterly lacking in homely comforts.
The exposure and the negative headlines forced councils to reconsider placing children with the firm involved and soon after all five of its properties in the West Midlands were shut down.
BREAKING: Children's homes where kids went 'missing overnight' shut down after sex attack claim
The summer sunshine triggered a new phenomenon across city communities - the raising of the flags of the Union and St George on lamp-posts. Before long hundreds of flags had appeared on major routes and housing estates across south Birmingham, rapidly spreading across the country.
The flagging of the city posed a massive dilemma for politicians, desperate not to label patriots as racists. They relied on public safety concerns to press for their removal, but that only seemed to inspire more flags to go up.
Not everyone liked this show of patriotism, nor the clear links that were evident between the flags and right wing politics, particularly anti migrant fervour. Many of those actively putting them up were also involved in protests outside hotels housing asylum seekers. In this article I sought to present the differing views.
READ MORE: 'We are patriotic not racist' - passions high as England and Union flags line Birmingham streets
READ MORE: West Midlands 'more divided and hateful' warning as racism 'going unchallenged'
The biggest concern was that heavily flagged areas gave people the impression of being a 'white British' enclave, with those not happy with them branded as 'non patriots' and 'lefties'. There were later direct confrontations in some parts of the city between those for and against the flagging.
SEPTEMBER
In September the region was shook by a racist rape reported by a young Sikh woman in Oldbury. The case remains unsolved.
Also this month, a whistleblower exposed new delays and problems with Birmingham's 'Oracle' IT project - the same one that had already ballooned from a £20 million scheme to one cost in excess of £200 million. My expose about the problem triggered an emergency meeting of the council's audit committee. Worryingly, the issue has still not been resolved.
Road safety was on our minds a lot in 2025, after a series of high profile crashes and hit and run incidents resulting in deaths and serious injuries.
As a result we launched the first of a series of campaigns on the topic - calling for a lifetime ban for killer and hit-and-run drivers who kill and maim.
You can read all about it here: Ban killer drivers for life
We also spotlighted some of the worst offenders. The killer drivers so bad we say 'ban them for life'
OCTOBER
Early in the month of October, four Birmingham Labour councillors quit their party in stinging resignations.
Soon after, the party also had to disown one of its remaining councillors after it was revealed he had attended the wedding of his brother in Pakistan who at the time was a fugitive who had fled justice over a drug running operation out of Birmingham. Saqib Khan was 'unselected' as a 2025 candidate as a result.
He wasn't the only councillor to face questions. Cllr Waseem Zaffar was to later deny any wrongdoing himself after pictures emerged of him socialising with a wanted fugitive said to be allegedly involved in a massive drug running operation out of Birmingham Airport. The Labour Party stood by him over the affair, accepting he had no idea about the criminal history of the man.
We kept up our focus on road deaths and injuries in the city, telling the heartbreaking story of the Birmingham mum who saw her four year old killed when they were both run down by a driver near their home in Highgate.
READ MORE: Birmingham mum relives moment killer driver struck four year old, ending life 'in a second'
In mid October another row erupted - this time when a Birmingham council-led safety advisory group and West Midlands Police agreed to ban fans of Maccabi Tel Aviv from a Europa League tie with Aston Villa.
Amid claims of antisemitism and calls for the police chief to resign, we picked over the details.
READ MORE: Missed chances to halt Maccabi Tel Aviv Villa Park fan ban revealed - and why no-one did
Elsewhere, there was a row inside Greater Birmingham Chamber of Commerce over racism.
A bigger racism furore was stirred up by Conservative MP Robert Jenrick who spoke disparagingly about Handsworth.
His comments about a lack of 'white faces' triggered a massive backlash.
The continued proliferation of unauthorised flags in parts of the city was also continuing to cause division. One man in Alvechurch tried to do something about it - only to get threats and anger directed at him as a result. Meanwhile, the council began to recruit staff to go out under cover of darkness and take them down.
Some of our coverage of the flags issue:
Council recruits staff to take them down
Birmingham flag wars erupt in quiet village as defiant dad faces death threats
Health Secretary Wes Streeting was in the city just as claims emerged he was mounting a leadership bid to take on Prime Minister Keir Starmer. There will be much more of this in 2026, especially if Labour performs badly in the local elections.
NOVEMBER
The Villa-Maccabi Tel Aviv match furore escalated. The game itself passed off relatively peacefully, with no injuries and a handful of arrests, but the fallout from the ban continues even now.
Among the follow up articles about the saga, I pulled together the truth about the intelligence used by West Midlands Police to prompt the ban on Maccabi fans, though that has also now been disputed.
Elsewhere, up in Sutton Coldfield a hotel that once was used as the setting for 1980s soap Crossroads was at the centre of protests over asylum seekers. In this exclusive, I suggested campaigners should pay more attention to the hotel's profiteering owners than its inhabitants, with millions raked in each year from the Home Office.
READ MORE: Sutton Coldfield hotel owners make millions from asylum seeker contracts
But the big story of the month was the unveiling of the vision for the new Blues stadium in east Birmingham. Knighthead, owners of Birmingham City FC, revealed their extraordinary, iconic new landmark for the city - it divided opinion, but everyone was agreed it would be a gamechanger for the city's prospects.
Birmingham City new stadium - live
Blues new stadium is unmistakeably Birmingham - but there's a problem
DECEMBER
It was hardly a festive tale - but it was one that has triggered an outporing of inquiries and tip offs, which will form the focus of a new investigation in the new year into the supported accommodation sector. Administrators brought in to oversee the future of an 'insolvent' Birmingham supported housing firm claim they encountered shocking incidents of threats, harassment, break-ins, arson attacks and deception.
I also told the story of the skiving Birmingham binman secretly filmed working as bouncer and playing football
And as the new year loomed, Birmingham City Council unveiled its plans to transform its bins services, with or without striking workers. The switch to fortnightly collections will begin in June. READ ALL ABOUT IT HERE
The equal pay bill was finally settled by the council - in this long read I shared the story of the union activist who didn't get to see the fruits of her efforts to get justice for women.
READ MORE: Birmingham council chiefs told 'come up with urgent plan to end bin strike' by government fixers
In a joyous finale to the year, BirminghamLive readers helped us and our partner charities to deliver 14,500 gifts to children in need across Birmingham under our #Brumwish initiative. Thanks to everyone who played their part.
